SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Class SQLQuery

java.lang.Object
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLStatement<SQLQuery>
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLQuery
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable
public final class SQLQuery extends SQLStatement<SQLQuery>

Facilitates the execution of SQL SELECT statements. SQLQuery instances are obtained via SQLSession.prepareQuery(). Here is an example of how to use the SQLQuery class: 


 SQL sql = SQL.simple("SELECT LAST_NAME FROM PERSON WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName");
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   try(SQLQuery query = sql.session(con).prepareQuery()) {
     query.bind("firstName", "John");
     // Collect all values in the first column of the ResultSet into a List
     List<String> lastNames = query.firstColumn();
   }
 }

Here is an example of a query that that contains both named parameters and template variables (see the comments for the SQL interface for the difference between the two): 


 SQL sql = SQL.template("""
  SELECT LAST_NAME
    FROM PERSON
   WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
   ORDER BY ~%sortColumn%
  """);
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   return sql.session(con)
       .setIdentifier("sortColumn", "SALARY")
       .prepareQuery()
       .bind("firstName", "John")
       .firstColumn();
 }

  • Method Details

    • lookup

      public <T> Result<T> lookup(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row. The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the value to be returned
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the value to be returned
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • getInt

      public Result<Integer> getInt()
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row as an Integer. Equivalent to lookup(Integer.class). The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • getString

      public Result<String> getString()
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row as a String. Equivalent to lookup(String.class). The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • exists

      public boolean exists()
      Executes the query and returns true if the query yielded at least one row; false otherwise. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed. Note that this method will call ResultSet.next(), moving the cursor to the next row in the ResultSet (it would look ugly, but you could even use it for precisely this purpose). This will influence the outcome of the other methods of SQLQuery, and of subsequent calls to exists() for that matter. Only call this method if the only thing you are interested in is whether a query yields a result (and nothing else).
      Returns:
      true if the query yielded at least one row; false otherwise

    • firstColumn

      public List<String> firstColumn()
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. Equivalent to firstColumn(String.class). If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • firstColumn

      public <T> List<T> firstColumn(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. Equivalent to firstColumn(clazz, 10). If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the desired type of the values
      Parameters:
      clazz - the desired class of the values
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • firstColumn

      public <T> List<T> firstColumn(Class<T> clazz, int sizeEstimate)
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. In other words, this method will retrieve all rows satisfying the WHERE and LIMIT clauses (if any) and collect the values of the first column into a List. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the desired type of the values
      Parameters:
      clazz - the desired class of the values
      sizeEstimate - the expected number of rows
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • getExtractor

      public MapExtractor getExtractor()

      Executes the query and returns a MapExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into Map<String, Object> pseudo-objects. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.

      Returns:
      a MapExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into Map<String, Object> pseudo objects.

    • getExtractor

      public <T> BeanExtractor<T> getExtractor(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans or records. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.

      Be wary of code like this: 

      
 BeanExtractor<Foo> extractor = SQL.simpleQuery(con, "SELECT * FROM FOO").getExtractor(Foo.class);

      This code does not close the temporary SQLQuery object from which you retrieve the BeanExtractor, and hence you may think you can safely use the BeanExtractor. But the SQLQuery object has gone out of scope by the time you receive the BeanExtractor, and Klojang JDBC makes sure that even if you do not close the SQLQuery, the JDBC resources associated with it will get closed once the SQLQuery object gets garbage-collected (more technically: once it becomes phantom-reachable, which is even sooner). Confusingly, you may sometimes get away with it and happily use the BeanExtractor — when it takes some time for the garbage collector to come around and reclaim the SQLQuery object. More often, though, the BeanExtractor will operate on a ResultSet that has already been closed. Request the BeanExtractor within a try-with-resource block created for the SQLQuery, or at least make sure the SQLQuery stays alive while you use the BeanExtractor.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the JavaBeans or records
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the JavaBeans or records
      Returns:
      a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans or records.

    • getExtractor

      public <T> BeanExtractor<T> getExtractor(Class<T> clazz, Supplier<T> beanSupplier)
      Executes the query and returns a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans. The provided class must not be a record type. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the JavaBeans (must not be a record type)
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the JavaBeans
      beanSupplier - the supplier of the JavaBean instances. This would ordinarily be a method reference to the constructor of the JavaBean (like Person::new)
      Returns:
      a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.

    • extract

      public <T> Optional<T> extract(FallibleFunction<ResultSet,T,SQLException> converter)
      Executes the query and converts the first row in the ResultSet into an object of type <T> using the specified conversion function. If the query yielded an empty ResultSet, the method returns an empty Optional. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again, and this method will convert the next row in the ResultSet. You can keep calling this method until an empty Optional is returned. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the objects into which the rows in the ResultSet are converted
      Parameters:
      converter - the conversion function. Do not call next() or close() on the ResultSet passed to the conversion function. This is the responsibility of the SQLQuery object.
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the object created from the current row in the ResultSet or an empty Optional if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • extract

      public <T> List<T> extract(int limit, FallibleFunction<ResultSet,T,SQLException> converter)

      Executes the query and converts at most limit rows in the ResultSet into objects of type <T> using the specified conversion function. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Thus, you can call this method again to retrieve and convert the next batch of rows from the ResultSet. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.

      This method is especially useful if the conversion process is too complicated to be carried out by a regular BeanExtractor, or if you want to eliminate all dynamic invocation (reflection, method handles) from the conversion process.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the objects into which the rows in the ResultSet are converted
      Parameters:
      limit - the maximum number of rows to extract from the ResultSet
      converter - the conversion function. Do not call next() or close() on the ResultSet passed to the conversion function. This is the responsibility of the SQLQuery object.
      Returns:
      a List of the objects created by the conversion function

    • extractAll

      public <T> List<T> extractAll(FallibleFunction<ResultSet,T,SQLException> converter)
      Equivalent to extractAll(10, converter).
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the objects into which the rows in the ResultSet are converted
      Parameters:
      converter - the conversion function. Do not call next() or close() on the ResultSet passed to the conversion function. This is the responsibility of the SQLQuery object.
      Returns:
      a List of the objects created by the conversion function

    • extractAll

      public <T> List<T> extractAll(int sizeEstimate, FallibleFunction<ResultSet,T,SQLException> converter)

      Executes the query and converts the rows in the ResultSet into objects of type <T> using the specified conversion function. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Thus, after a call to this method, you should really close the SQLQuery instance or call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.

      This method is especially useful if the conversion process is too complicated to be carried out by a regular BeanExtractor, or if you want to eliminate all dynamic invocation (reflection, method handles) from the conversion process.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the objects into which the rows in the ResultSet are converted
      Parameters:
      sizeEstimate - an estimate of the number of rows in the ResultSet
      converter - the conversion function. Do not call next() or close() on the ResultSet passed to the conversion function. This is the responsibility of the SQLQuery object.
      Returns:
      a List of the objects created by the conversion function

    • getResultSet

      public ResultSet getResultSet()

      Executes the query and returns the result. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Instead, the ResultSet generated by the first call to execute() will be returned. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed. Since the returned ResultSet is the same one that underpins this instance, be careful what you do with it. For example, if you close the ResultSet, but then continue to use this instance, an exception is almost guaranteed to follow. Klojang JDBC does not protect itself against such unintended usage. Also, be wary of code like this: 

      
 ResultSet rs = SQL.simpleQuery(con, "SELECT * FROM FOO").getResultSet();

      This code does not close the temporary SQLQuery object from which you retrieve the ResultSet, and hence you may think you can safely use the ResultSet. But the SQLQuery object goes out of scope once you have received the ResultSet, and Klojang JDBC makes sure that even if you do not close the SQLQuery, the JDBC resources associated with it will get closed once the SQLQuery object gets garbage-collected. Confusingly, you may sometimes get away with it and happily use the ResultSet — when it takes some time for the garbage collector to come around and reclaim the SQLQuery object. More often, though, the ResultSet will be dead on arrival.

      Returns:
      the query result

    • close

      public void close()
      Description copied from class: SQLStatement
      Releases all resources held by this instance. You cannot reuse the instance after a call to this method.
